intro: Phymatodes sinuata, commonly known as the Mexican yarrow, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is a member of the Asteraceae family, characterized by its composite flower heads and aromatic foliage. The plant typically grows in dry, rocky soils and is often found in desert or semi-arid environments. Its leaves are narrow and lance-shaped, with a rough, hairy texture, while its flowers are small and yellow, arranged in flat-topped clusters. Phymatodes sinuata is known for its resilience to drought and its ability to thrive in poor soil conditions.
